ROW.REGULATORY_INTERACTION_NOTE:
The CRP-binding site controlling the lacZp1 promoter was enhanced up to 14-fold or abolished by varying the N6 spacer sequence, which is part of the consensus sequence of the dimer that recognizes a 20-bp region through direct amino acid nucleotide interactions in the major groove of the two operator half-sites |CITS:[24387622]|.
Crystal structure analyses revealed that the interaction results in two strong kinks at the TG/CA steps closest to the 6-bp spacer (N6), and the authors proposed that the underlying mechanism relies on N6 deformability |CITS:[24387622]|.
This regulatory interaction was identified by means of PhoPQ-related microarray experiments and it was checked for the presence of its regulatory motif in the promoter region |CITS: [15883881]|.

Additional evidence supports this TF-gene interaction with no precise position defined.

MelR binding to site 2' (-194.5) occurs only in the presence of melibiose |CITS:[12060687]| and relieves MelR-dependent repression of the melR promoter |CITS:[12060687], [10760179], [10747919], [1445208], [10760178]|.

Binding of MelR to a fifth site (R) that overlaps the melR promoter has been shown to downregulate expression from the melR promoter |CITS[10760179], [10760178], [16621812]|.
Helix-turn-helix 2 of MelR contacts the downstream part of site +1.5 at the bp 5 and 13 of the consensus sequence |CITS:[ 12675795][18346968]|.

This regulatory interaction was identified by means of PhoPQ-related microarray experiments, and it was investigated to determine the presence of its regulatory motif in the promoter region |CITS: [15883881]|.

When the CTP level within the cell is high relative to the level of GTP, the pyrC gene is transcribed from a start site that allows formation of a secondary structure within the 5' end of the mRNA. This hairpin structure is thought to obscure the Shine-Dalgarno sequence, and it results in poor translation efficiency. When the CTP level is low relative to the level of GTP, pyrC is transcribed from an alternate start site. This shorter mRNA is translated efficiently. The PurR protein, which represses the pyrC gene, is also regulated by the level of GTP, because this protein is active when GTP is present.
CRP activates the fisP1 promoter in the absence of FIS, but if FIS is present, together FIS and CRP repress fis gene transcription.

Based on the effect of various concentrations of GalS on the gal regulon promoter and mathematical models, it was determined that GalS has higher affinity for galSOE, which is at position -61.5 on the galS promoter |CITS:[19429616]|. This effect is referred to as dominant negative autoregulation |CITS:[19429616]|.
GalR is required to bind HU.
HU and GalR, binding two sites, repress the expression of the gal operon in the total absence of galactose |CITS: [16524589]|.
GalR is required to facilitate HU binding.
HU and GalR, binding two sites, repress the expression of the gal operon in the total absence of galactose |CITS: [16524589]|.
Although the internal operators required sites at +1 and +20 for repression in vivo, these sites were not required to demonstrate the binding of GlpR to sites +415.5 and +456.5.

An interesting characteristic of the regulation of the ilvLBN operon is that even though CRP can activate it,
attenuation can trump any activation by CRP and absolutely stop ilvLBN transcription |CITS: [6095192]|.

FruR cannot bind to its site in the aceBAK regulatory region in the presence of fructose-1-phosphate, and the inference of the positive effect of FruR for the activation of this operon was proved for S. typhimurium (by gene expression analysis) by |CITS: [2496106]|, and just confirmed for E. coli by |CITS: [8230205]|, providing further evidence of its localization in the regulatory region of the aceBAK operon.

Under inducing conditions (growth on acetate), IHF activates aceBAK expression by opposing IclR repression. In contrast, IHF has little effect on aceBAK expression under repressing conditions (growth on glucose).

Under inducing conditions (growth on acetate), IHF activates aceBAK expression by opposing IclR repression. In contrast, IHF has little effect on aceBAK expression under repressing conditions (growth on glucose).
Ada activates alkA transcription via direct interaction with σ70 region 4 |CITS:[10049384]|.

A with sequence different from the ModE consensus sequence (where adenines in TATAT-N7-TAYAT were replaced by guanines, TGTGT-N7-TGYGT) was found upstream of deoCp2, which overlaps with the -40.5 site of CRP |CITS: [16205910]|.

mismatch |CITS:[12079504]|.

As an earlier study had described a negative effect in a fruR mutant of S. enterica serovar Typhimurium for the expression of pckA |CITS: [2496106]|, it was inferred that FruR could activate pckA transcription. Now as the FruR site was found 145 bp upstream of the transcriptional start site (similar to the ace operon site), the suggestion is that FruR is able to activate gene expression at a considerable distance, possibly looping the DNA in order to contact the transcriptional initiation complex.

MarA plays a very important role in the complex negative regulation of the hdeAB-yhiD operon during the stationary phase and acid resistance that depends on the growth conditions, on other regulators of hdeAB-yhiD expression, and on the degree of induction of marA expression. MarA also controls it, by modifying the effects of the other regulators. This transcriptional regulator binds to a \ marbox\ partially overlapping the -35 box of the hdeAp promoter, competing with the RNA polymerase for DNA binding and/or direct interactions between MarA and σ70, σ38, or other subunits of RNA polymerase. In addition, several putative binding sites are located near the \ marbox\ . MarA reduces the repression caused by GadX and Lrp during exponential phase and it helps H-NS repression, although it is not clear how. On the other hand, MarA reduces the ability of GadE to activate the hdeAB-yhiD operon during the stationary phase, since they compete for DNA binding or for interacting. This regulator also reduces the repression caused by GadW during stationary phase. Finally, MarA seems to compete functionally with GadX, GadW, RpoS, and Lrp under some conditions, which might ensure that hdeAB-yhiD expression is not repressed more than necessary |CITS: [18083817]|.

H-NS represses transcription through the binding to supercoiled DNA |CITS: [8455549]|. H-NS represses the transcription initiation at hdeAp by σ70, but not by σ38. This repression is not through a direct interaction with σ70; instead, it acts as a cofactor for DNA looping. H-NS bound at 118 laterally extends to the promoter downstream sequence and wraps the DNA around σ70 through the cooperative recruitment of other H-NS molecules |CITS: [16204188]|.
H-NS is the main repressor of the hdeAB-yhiD operon. Both H-NS and GadE are involved in increasing the hdeAB-yhiD repression levels by MarA that occur as the cell enters the stationary phase |CITS: [18083817]|.
The FruR site in the pfkA gene overlaps with the -35 box, so it is proposed that FruR inhibits pfkA transcription, avoiding the RNA polymerase access to its binding site.
CRP has a positive effect on dgsAp2 transcription directed by σ70. However, CRP has little effect on dgsAp2 transcription directed by σ32.
CRP binds in just one site and activates argG gene expresion and represses the expression of the divergent operon, metY-yhbC-nusA-infB.
CRP and anaerobiosis are required for the hyf operon expression when the HyfR protein is the activator |CITS: [14702328]|.
Only FhlA mutants can activate the transcription of the hyf operon. The HycA protein acts as an antiactivator of FhlA |CITS:[12426353]|.
HypF activates hyf operon transcription only when it is expressed from a heterologous promoter |CITS: [12426353] [14702328]|.

This site has low affinity for IHF. The low affinity of IHF binding suggests a simple mechanism for the negative autoregulation of IHF, in which IHF acts as a repressor of transcription initiation only when its level in the cell is high. The increase in the level of IHF as the cell enters the stationary phase is partly caused by the increase in the mRNA level of the two IHF genes.

The effect of FruR repression of the adhE gene was studied under aerobic and anaerobic growth conditions, and stronger repression was observed during aerobic growth. Neither respiratory condition implies direct regulation, but they may reflect a difference of fructose or fructose-1,6-diphosphate levels |CITS: [9371462]|. Later, the FruR site was localized downstream of the promoter, and it has been proposed as a repressor site |CITS: [12083772]| (as it has been observed that other FruR repressor sites are overlapping or downstream of the promoter) (see |CITS: [8655535]|).
Although Crp has been observed to bind to this site, its function remains unknown.

In 2000, Ibanez et al showed that transcription of the divergent operon yiaJ-yiaKLMNO-lyxK-sgbHUE depends on the PlaR (YiaJ) repressor. However, the authors suggested that this regulator binds a long region of 35 bp |CITS: [10913096]|. The alignment of this region with the orthologous sequence of Klebsiella pneumoniae showed a conserved palindrome of 21 bp |CITS: [18708499]|. The position and length of the PlaR binding site have been changed to reflect this.

The TyrR-binding site at position bp 20.5 from the aroPp2 promoter is a strong TyrR box that is involved in the repression of aroP gene transcription |CITS:[10515932]|. This strong box, which is closest to the promoter, is critical for repression, due to the fact that this site is bound by TyrR as a dimer or as a hexamer. The weak box has a less significant role in aroPp2 repression |CITS:[10515932]|.

This regulatory interaction was identified by means of PhoPQ-related microarray experiments, and it was checked for the presence of the regulatory motif in the promoter region |CITS: [15883881]|. A repressor function for acrAB operon transcription can be clearly anticipated from the localization of the PhoP-binding site, very close to the acrAp promoter core region.

The regulatory effect of IHF on the promoter yiaJp is not yet known. However, we assigned a negative effect to this regulatory interaction based on the fact that the protein-binding site is very close to the promoter (4 bp upstream from the transcription start site).

GadE is required both for gadA/gadBC expression during exponential growth and stationary phase expression. GadE is an acid-induced regulator, since it is involved in the acid induction of gadA/gadBC operons during exponential growth. The expression of these operons is maybe one of the most intensively regulated systems in Escherichia coli since it is regulated by different factors. GadE and GadX could simultaneously bind to the GAD box region of gadA/gadBC and form a complex |CITS: [12940989]|.

This potential site could belong to the CRP regulator since it possesses 9 of the 16 consensus nucleotides associated with CRP binding |CITS: [11238978]|. GadE and CRP bind to this site, controlling gadB expression during both growth under acidic conditions and in stationary phase.

IHF plays a dual role in controlling fimA expression: it is required both for inversion of the fimA control region and for efficient expression from the fimA promoter.
The transcription factor-binding site (TFBS) for IHF is in a region that is part of a 314-bp invertible region whose inversion is necessary to activate ("on" orientation) or to inactivate ("off" orientation) the fimA promoter |CITS:[9157242]|. The sequence in the database is that of the off orientation, and thus the TFBS is located downstream of the transcriptional start site (TSS), at position +77, and its sequence is shown in the inverted direction. When the region is inverted, this TFBS is located in the correct position (bp -76 from the TSS) and correct orientation (TATCAAACAGTTA) to be functional for activation of the fimA promoter |CITS:[9157242], [2886490]|.

This transcription factor-binding site (TFBS) called site 3 for Lrp is in a region that is part of a 314-bp invertible region whose inversion is necessary to activate (on orientation) or to inactivate ("off" orientation) the fimA promoter. The sequence of site 3 in the database is shown in the off orientation. It is located downstream of the transcriptional start site (TSS) at position +173, and its sequence is shown in the inverted direction. When the region is inverted, this TFBS is located in the correct position (-174 from the TSS) and correct orientation (GAGAGAAGAATGAGG). In the presence of leucine, the recombination that causes sequence inversion is stimulated by disruption of the binding of Lrp to this TFBS (site 3) |CITS: [9515701]|. Additional evidence supports this TF-gene interaction with no precise position defined.

The transcription factor-binding site (TFBS) for Lrp, called site 2, is in a region that is part of a 314-bp invertible region whose inversion is necessary to activate (" on" orientation) or to inactivate ("off" orientation) the fimA promoter |CITS:[7916011]|. Lrp binding to site 1 and site 2 is required to bias inversion to the on orientation of the invertible region |CITS:[16855224]|. The sequence of site 2 in the database is shown in the off orientation, and therefore it is located downstream of the transcriptional start site (TSS) at the bp +235 position; its sequence is shown in the inverted direction. When the region is inverted, this TFBS is located in the correct position (-234 from the TSS) and correct orientation (TGGCTTAATATTCTA) |CITS:[7916011]|.
Additional evidence supports this TF-gene interaction with no precise position defined.

This transcription factor-binding site (TFBS) called site 1 for Lrp is in a region that is part of a 314-bp invertible region whose inversion is necessary to activate (on orientation) or to inactivate ("off" orientation) the fimA promoter |CITS:[7916011]|. Lrp binding to site 1 and site 2 is required to bias inversion to the on orientation of the invertible region |CITS:[16855224]|. The sequence of site 1 in the database is shown in the off orientation, and therefore it is located downstream of the transcriptional start site (TSS) at position +204, and its sequence is shown in the inverted direction. When the region is inverted, this TFBS is located in the correct position (bp -203 from the TSS) and correct orientation (TAGATGTTTATATTG) |CITS:[7916011]|.
Additional evidence supports this TF-gene interaction with no precise position defined.

IHF plays a dual role in controlling fimA expression: it is required both for inversion of the fimA control region and for efficient expression from the fimA promoter.
This transcription factor-binding site (TFBS) for IHF is very close to a 314-bp invertible region whose inversion is necessary to activate ("on" orientation) or to inactivate ("off" orientation) the fimA promoter |CITS:[9157242]|. The sequence in the database is shown in the off orientation, in which this TFBS is located at bp -52 from the transcriptional start site (TSS). When the region is inverted to the on orientation, this TFBS is moved to the correct position (-341 bp from the TSS) to be functional and activate fimA promoter |CITS:[9157242], [2886490]|.

The regulatory effect of IHF on the rtcB promoter is not yet known. However, we assigned a positive effect to this regulatory interaction based on the protein's binding site, which is upstream of the promoter (62 bp upstream of the transcription start site).

The regulatory effect of IHF on the rtcB promoter is as yet not known. However, we assigned a positive effect to this regulatory interaction based on the protein's binding site being upstream of the promoter (52 bp upstream of the transcription start site).
CaiF and CRP bind cooperatively to the cai-fix intergenic region to activate the fixA promoter.
CaiF and CRP bind cooperatively to the cai-fix intergenic region to activate the fixA promoter.
Stimulation of the nfop promoter was independent of the C-terminal domain of the RNA polymerase α-subunit. The binding site overlaps the -35 promoter hexamer.

ArcA regulation in this promoter shows a strong dependence on IHF . This ArcA-binding site straddles the transcription start site of the focAp1 promoter and it may be required for formation of a stable closed complex between Fnr and RNA polymerase at the focAp1 promoter.

ArcA positive regulation shows a strong dependence on IHF, and this ArcA-binding site is located upstream of the IHF-binding site. ArcA has a higher affinity for this ArcA-binding site than for the two other ArcA-binding sites.

This IHF-binding site located between two putative FNR- binding sites is absolutely necessary for pyruvate-mediated induction of the focA-pflB operon. IHF also has a positive role in the anaerobic induction mediated by ArcA of the focA-pflB operon |CITS: [8376324]|.
The CRP-binding site is the same as the FNR-binding site, with a center position at -41.5.

The regulatory effect of IHF on the promoter micFp1 is not yet known. However, we have assigned a negative effect to this regulatory interaction based on the fact that the protein's binding site overlaps the transcription start site of the promoter.
Marginally stimulated by CRP-cAMP. When the template is linear, transcriptional initiation is switched from POa to POb, 3 bp farther upstream from POa, and transcription becomes more CRP dependent.
FruR could repress ptsHP1b transcription by displacing CRP-cAMP from its binding site, thus restoring ptsHp2 activity from CRP-cAMP inhibition |CITS: [7852310]|.
CRP binds to the ptsHP2 promoter when there is a superhelicoidal template in vitro.
FadR represses uspA gene expression during log phase.
FadR represses uspA gene expression during log phase. This site shows some weak FadR binding, and it exhibits little homology to other FarR-binding sites.

Lrp binds to one or more sites within the region from -80 to -32 relative to the start point of lrp transcription. In vitro Lrp binds a region just upstream from the lrp promoter. With the deletion of this region, autogenous regulation by Lrp in vivo is lost. The region protected by Lrp from the DNase I cleavage is at 105 to -20 relative to the start point of lrp transcription. There are two sequences that match with the consensus of Lrp located at -67 to -53 and at +14 to +28. A cluster of single-base substitutions within the region -60 to -53 prevents binding of lrp in vitro and significantly reduces repression of lrp caused by lrp
in vivo.

Lrp activates the gltBDF operon in a leucine-insensitive manner |CITS:[7901196]|, binding at three sites distant to the σ70 promoter. This is a strange way of regulating a σ70 promoter, since Lrp should bind close to the promoter in order to regulate, and so it is helped by IHF (the DNA-bending protein) binding between the proximal Lrp site and the promoter, bending this DNA region and getting Lrp closer to σ70 to activate the transcription |CITS:[11395454]|. (Lrp is just a modulator of the operon expression; it does not work as the common activators/repressors that switch the gene expression in an on/off manner. In addition, it is sometimes insensitive to the presence of leucine to have its modulator effect |CITS:[7968922]|.)
Additional evidence supports this TF-gene interaction with no precise position defined.

CRP binding to site 2 (+17.5) causes little or no repression on the malI promoter, while CRP binding to site 1 (-43.5) causes only weak activation. It could be that malI has an unusual organization of its peculiar sequence |CITS:[19054084]|.
IdnR negatively controls the gntK operon, presumably by binding to GntR-binding elements when GntR is released from the operator by interaction with gluconate.

When the template is linear, transcriptional initiation is switched from POa to POb, 3 bp farther upstream from POa, and transcription becomes more CRP dependent. There is no PO expression in the absence of CRP or cAMP in the cell, unless glucose is present.
CRP binds to the ptsHP1 promoter when there is a superhelicoidal template in vitro.

A high concentration of FruR was needed for ptsHP1b repression in vitro. FruR could repress pstHP1b transcription by displacing CRP-cAMP from its binding site, thus restoring P1a activity from CRP-cAMP inhibition |CITS: [7852310]|.
The positive effect of the cAMP-CRP complex is seen only together with DsdC. Thus, CRP cannot act by itself in this system.
The positive effect of the cAMP-CRP complex is seen only together with DsdC. Thus, CRP cannot act on its own in this system.

ArcA mediates anaerobic regulation of the focA-pflB operon. Its positive regulation shows a strong dependence on IHF. This ArcA-binding site overlaps the transcription start site of the focAp2 promoter. The binding of ArcA to this site may be required for the formation of a stable closed complex between Fnr and RNA polymerase at the focAp3 promoter. Clearly, it will be necessary to examine the occupancy of this site by ArcA in the presence of RNA polymerase and FNR before any speculation can be made as to the physiological relevance of this binding site, although in vivo studies using an arcA mutant have clearly established that ArcA is essential for transcription from the focAp3 promoter.
The CsgD protein-binding site overlaps the -35 box of the csgBp promoter, which is consistent with the location for an activator-binding site |CITS: [14523117]|.

Additional evidence supports this TF-gene interaction with no precise position defined.

When the CTP level within the cell is high relative to the level of GTP, the pyrD gene is transcribed from a start site that allows formation of a secondary structure within the 5' end of the mRNA. This hairpin structure is thought to obscure the Shine-Dalgarno sequence, and it results in poor translation efficiency. When the CTP level is low relative to the level of GTP, pyrD is transcribed from an alternate start site. These shorter mRNAs are translated efficiently. The PurR protein, which represses the pyrD gene, is also regulated by the level of GTP, because this protein is active when GTP is present, but when PurR is active it repress the two genes, and when there is a high level of GTP these genes are translated efficiently. Thus, the two control systems can operate in opposition to one another.

Activation of the icd gene is proposed to be via Cra bending the DNA region of the promoter icdAp2. Transcription is activated only when Cra and RNA polymerase bind to opposite faces of the DNA helix (similar to the ppsA promoter). Cra would compensate for the absence of an upstream (UP) element in icdp2, changing the structure of proximal DNA so as to make it operate like a UP module |CITS: [9922253]|.
rhaT is under the RhaR-RhaS cascade for induction by L-rhamnose.

The TyrR-binding site at position -64.5 from the promoter is a strong TyrR box that is involved in the activation and repression of tyrP gene transcription. The effect of RcsB on rcsA expression depends on the presence of the RcsA protein. There is a putative Rcs box (RcsA-RcsB)-binding site in the rcsA promoter region. Direct interaction of RcsB and/or RcsA in the E. coli rcsA promoter region remains to be shown. The RcsB effect on rcsA expression can be overcome by excess RcsA, indicating that RcsB functions as an auxiliary factor in rcsA expression.

In the absence of the other proteins, cAMP-CRP binds to three CRP targets centered at -92.5 (CRP2), -42.5 (CRP1), and +56 (CRPE). The importance of CRPE located within the nupG coding region is at present unknown.

The nupG full repression complex contains the CytR protein sandwiched between two cAMP-CRP complexes. Binding of CytR to its target excludes binding of cAMP-CRP to CRP1 and promotes binding of cAMP-CRP to CRP0, therefore allowing cooperative binding of the two protein species.

Previously, two binding sites for the NagC repressor were detected upstream of manX, but a mutation in nagC has very little effect on manX expression. Plasmids overproducing either the NagC protein or the Mlc protein repress the expression of manX, but the effect of the Mlc protein is stronger |CITS: [9484892], [1848637]|.

A mutation in the mlc gene, encoding a homolog of nagC, results in a threefold derepression of manX expression, suggesting that this protein is a more important regulator of maX expression than NagC. The Mlc protein binds to the NagC operators, binding preferentially to the promoter-proximal operator. Plasmids overproducing either the NagC protein or the mlc protein repress the expression of manX, but the effect to the Mlc protein is stronger. Mcl weakly protects this operator. The manX operator is only partially occupied under physiological concentrations of the Mlc protein. Purified OxyR and IHF proteins have also been shown to bind upstream of the dps promoter. IHF is required for the σS-dependent promoter. dps is induced in stationary phase. OxyR and IHF proteins may occupy the dps promoter simultaneously |CITS: [7984106]|.

OxyR and σS act independently to regulate the level of the Dps protein in the log and the stationary phases. Regulation of dps by σS and OxyR is independent in vivo, and OxyR probably does not activate σS holoenzyme. OxyR and IHF proteins may occupy the dps promoter simultaneously |CITS: [7984106]|.

A model has been proposed in which ModE-molybdate serves as a secondary transcriptional activator of both the hyc and narXL operons, which are activated primarily by the transcriptional activators FhlA and NarL, respectively. Both ModE and MoeA are needed for maximal expression of the hyc operon. MoeA does not bind DNA |CITS:[9851041]|, and it was suggested that it activates molybdenum by sulfurylation |CITS:[9515915]|.

The Crp effect is relatively weak.

The protein CysB regulates the expression of the cysDNC operon. This protein was previously indicated as involved in regulating the cydD and cysNC promoters. But the cysNC promoter has been eliminated from the database. See the note for the cysD promoter and the note for the transcription unit cysDNC.

Early work with an sdh-galk fusion indicates that crp and cya are required for maximum expression, and S1 mapping studies not only confirmed that sdh transcription is severely repressed by glucose but indicated that there is a potential CRP-binding site at -80 in the sdh promoter region.
This promoter and its CRP-binding site are responsible for the coordinate expression and the glucose-mediated repression of ODH and SCS synthesis.

IHF, located at -127 from the nrfAp promoter, is necessary to activate the FNR-dependent transcription of the nrfABCDEFG operon , but only in the absence of NarL/NarP |CITS:[16936015]|.

NarP appears to weakly antagonize the activation of nrfA by NarL at low nitrate concentrations |CITS:[11004182]|.
nrf expression is increased in response to nitrite or nitrate ions by NarL or NarP. FNR and NarL/NarP act by promoting open complex formation by RNAP at the nrf promoter. Although it seems that NarL and FNR can bind to their targets independently, NarL is unable to activate the nrf promoter in the absence of FNR |CITS: [15978080]|. NarL and IHF cannot bind together, and the other protein regulator can bind together to form ternary complexes. Fis binds independently of FNR and IHF. |CITS: [15978080]| supposed that Fis block access of RNAP to the nrf promoter.
At low levels of nitrate, NarL activates nrfA expression and at high levels of nitrate NarL represses it.

IHF binding to a site located -55 bp from the promoter weakly represses the nrfAp promoter and strongly represses acsP1, a promoter that overlaps and is divergent to nrfAp.
NarL and IHF cannot bind together, contrary to other protein regulators that can bind together to form ternary complexes. Fis binds independently to FNR and IHF. |CITS: [15978080]| supposes that Fis blocks access of RNAP to the nrf promoter. Based on DNase footprinting |CITS:[15978080]|, it is suggested that IHF alters the binding of FNR without displacing it from its site. In addition, NarL binding prevents IHF binding but has little or no effect on FNR or Fis binding. Either Fis or IHF at -55 can repress FNR-dependent open complex formation. NarL binding to its target reverses IHF-dependent repression but does not relieve Fis-dependent repression |CITS:[15978080]|.
The -22 and -50 NarL sites are needed for optimal repression of nrfA expression. At high nitrate concentrations NarL can repress nrfA expression, but NarP cannot |CITS:[11004182] |.

RcsB is apparently essential for cps expression. As a matter of fact, both RcsA and RcsB are required for optimal cps expression, since cps expression in an rcsB strain is low and cps expression cannot be activated by RcsA in the absence of RcsB, suggesting an auxiliary role in cps expression. But RcsA is not absolutely dependent on RcsB. There are no in vitro data that demonstrate RcsA binding to the cps promoter region. Thus, direct interaction of RcsB and/or RcsA in the E. coli cps promoter region remains to be shown. RcsA and RcsB are proposed to form heterodimers in order to be functional in the activation of cps. Multicopy RcsB can overcome the absence of RcsA to activate cps expression. Osmotic shock has been shown to be dependent on RcsA, RcsB, RcsC, and MdoH. Several global regulators bind and repress cps, such as CRP and H-NS.

Based on EMSE, it was demonstrated that His6-ArgP has an apparent Kd of 35 nM for the binding of ArgP to the dapB regulatory region |CITS:[18502871]|.

The role for the nemRA-gloA operon is to sense electrophiles |CITS:[23506073]|.
Bleach upregulates the NemR-controlled genes gloA and nemA and increases bacterial survival in bleach, and this finding provided the first evidence that resistance toward bleach relies on the ability of bacteria to detoxify methylglyoxal and reactive electrophiles |CITS:[23536188]|.

CRP binding to site 2 (+17.5) causes little or no repression on the malI promoter, while CRP binding to site 1 (-43.5) causes only weak activation. It could be that malI has an unusual organization of its peculiar sequence |CITS:[19054084]|.
FruR is unable to bind to its ppsA site in the presence of fructose-1-phosphate (during glycolysis), in which case the ppsA transcription activation is avoided |CITS: [8230205]|.

The nir promoter is 100% dependent on FNR. If there is no FNR, there is no activity. This activity can be efficiently repressed by FruR (-16.5 site) and less efficiently by HNS and Fis (+23 site). FNR-dependent activation of the nir promoter is repressed by IHF (-88 site) and Fis (-142 site), DNA-binding proteins that play a role in shaping the folded bacterial chromosome. Although Fis and IHF repress FNR-dependent activation of the nir promoter, they do not prevent FNR binding. Thus, Fis, IHF, and FNR can bind simultaneously.

The spacing between the FNR site and the RNA polymerase site is critical in the expression of dmsA .
FNR activates dmsA expression under anaerobic environmental conditions |CITS:[12079504]| and under mock ionizing radiation conditions |CITS: [30673695]|.
FNR upregulates nikABCDE in the absence of oxygen. This regulator is inactivated by O2 |CITS:[16159764]|.

The N-terminal domain of NikR is responsible for DNA recognition.
NikR and NarLX repress the synthesis of NikABCDE in the presence of nitrate. NikR also represses NikABCDE expression at higher nickel concentrations. This regulator is activated by Ni2+, and its function is inhibited by one or more formate-inducible hydrogenase assembly components |CITS:[16159764]|.
Nitric oxide (NO) inactivates the FNR protein, so NO induces hmpA expression .

It seems that Fnr repress the hyf operon expression when it is activated by HyfR. Its is possible that binding of FNR may minimize the binding of HyfR, whose binding site is only 25 bases upstream of the FNR-binding site |CITS: [14702328]|.

It has been shown that the dnaAN-recF operon is not regulated in vivo by ArgP |CITS:[21890697]|. However, ArgP slightly binds to the regulatory regions of dnaAp1 in vitro, as it exhibits low-affinity binding to ArgP |CITS:[21890697]|.
An unknown factor other than Fnr also contributes to anaerobic induction of dcuB.
Fnr can regulate adhE expression from the adhEp2 promoter only in the physical absence of the upstream promoter region.
During anaerobic growth Fnr is important for hlyE expression.
Under anaerobiosis, FNR repress cydAB operon expression |CITS: [12754220]|.
FNR activates hypB transcription under anaerobiosis.

Both proteins, FNR and ArcA, activate the expression of fumB under anaerobiosis, but they act independently from each other. This site has eight identities with regard to the symmetrical consensus TTGATA--TATCAA proposed by Spiro and Guest for FNR |CITS:[1957353]|. There are also two half-sites with five and four identities. The significance of the potential FNR sites is difficult to assess, partly because their homologies with the consensus are not particularly strong.

nrf regulation is totally dependent on FNR at this site (-41.5) under anaerobic conditions. FNR and NarL/NarP act by promoting the open complex formation by RNA polymerase at the nrf promoter. Although it seems that NarL and FNR can bind to their targets independently, NarL is unable to activate the nrf promoter in the absence of FNR |CITS: [15978080]|. Based on DNase I footprinting |CITS: [15978080]| suggest that IHF alters the binding of FNR without displacing it from its site. In adittion, NarL binding prevents IHF binding but has little or no effect on FNR or Fis binding.

Bound RcnR (RcnR transcriptional repressor) represses transcription |CITS:[16956381][17120142][19703465]|. RcnR interacts nonspecifically with the approximately 50 bp flanking the core binding site, resulting in DNA wrapping and the introduction of a single negative supercoil into plasmid DNA |CITS:[19703465]|.

CytR and CRP act together to repress transcription from the rpoHp5 promoter. A single CytR molecule binds between two CRP molecules. CRP-CytR-CRP.
CytR and CRP act in concert to repress transcription from the rpoHp3 promoter. A single CytR molecule binds between two CRP molecules. CRP-CytR-CRP

The nupG full repression complex contains the CytR protein sandwiched between two cAMP-CRP complexes. Binding of CytR to its target excludes binding of cAMP-CRP to CRP1 and promotes binding of cAMP-CRP to CRP0, therefore allowing cooperative binding of the two protein species.
CRP and CytR bind cooperatively to cddp.

GadE is required both for gadA/gadBC expression during exponential growth and stationary-phase expression. GadE is an acid-induced regulator since it is involved in the acid induction of gadA/gadBC operons during exponential growth. The expression of these operons may be one of the most intensively regulated systems in Escherichia coli, since it is regulated by different factors. GadE and GadX may simultaneously bind to the GAD box region of gadA/gadBC and form a complex |CITS: [12940989]|.

In 2000, Ibanez et al showed that transcription of the divergent operon yiaJ-yiaKLMNO-lyxK-sgbHUE depends on the YiaJ repressor. However, the authors suggested that this regulator binds a long region of 35 bp |CITS: [10913096]|. The alignment of this region with the orthologous sequence of Klebsiella pneumoniae showed a conserved palindrome of 21 bp |CITS: [18708499]|. The position and length of the YiaJ binding site have been changed to reflect this.

The site for IHF (-173.5), determined experimentally by DNase I footprinting, covers a region of 30 bp upstream of csgDp1 |CITS: [20466769]|]. It is likely that there are several sites for IHF, so the consensus sequence for this regulator is 13 bp.
OmpR-P represses ompF at high osmolarity |CITS:[2656631]|.
CaiF and CRP bind cooperatively to the cai-fix intergenic region to activate the fixA promoter.
CaiF and CRP bind cooperatively to the cai-fix intergenic region to activate the fixA promoter.

McbR activates σS-dependent transcription at yciGp by countering the negative effect of H-NS |CITS:[20713450]|, i.e., σS induces expression of the yciGFE operon only when H-NS-mediated repression is relieved. Repression of yciGFE by H-NS is inversely correlated with σS levels |CITS:[20713450]|.
The ArcAB two-component system represses arcZ expression under anaerobic growth |CITS:[20683441]|. Thus, ArcA represses rpoS translation through ArcZ |CITS:[20683441]|.
BluF can interact with MlrA, antagonizing its effects in vitro, and when BluF is overexpressed in vivo it interferes with csgD expression |CITS: [22783906]|.

The MlrA-cadCp regulatory interaction was identified by sequence analysis reported by Ogasawara et al., and by a gel shift assay using purified transcription factor (data not provided) |CITS[20874755]|.

There is communication over a distance of 200 bp between site I, associated with the yqjIp promoter, and site II, which is associated with the yqjHp promoter, that provides full YqjI-dependent regulation at two target promoters |CITS:[24982304]|.
Extended footprinting analysis demonstrated that the yqjIp promoter (site II) is greater than 20 bp, which represents the length of the consensus sequences for the YqjI transcription factor |CITS:[24982304]|. Site I may contain only half of the full-length apo-YqjI operator, while site II contains the entire binding site |CITS:[24982304]|. YqjI had the highest affinity for site II, consist with this site containing the full-length operator rather than only a half-site |CITS:[24982304]|.
There are two repetitive extragenic palindromic (REP) sequences within the yqjH-yqjI intergenic region; these REP sequences are not required for YqjI regulation |CITS:[24982304]|.

J. Oberto in 2010 identified a possible binding site for NagC, GGTAATTCACTATTCGAATTATA, in the upstream region of the feoA gene. The demonstration was based on different statistical methods |CITS:[21070640]|. In this case the regulator requires two binding sites to repress the transcription of the feoA gene, and for this reason the function of this binding site cannot be predicted.

Even though the studies of FruR regulation of fruBKA were done in Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium, the inferences can be applied to E. coli also |CITS: [8230205]|. It was observed that in presence of fructose-1-phosphate FruR cannot bind to its fruB site, allowing its transcription. In addition, two FruR operators have been observed in the regulatory region of fruBKA, so a repression mechanism of FruR for this operon has been proposed: as the two operators are distant, FruR binds to both sites and bends the DNA, avoiding the RNA polymerase access to the promoter. For a discussion of the serovar Typhimurium evidence see |CITS: [8230205]|.

The acrR gene, which is located upstream of and in the opposite direction of acrAB, encodes AcrR, a negative DNA-binding transcriptional regulator for a multidrug efflux pump. The presence of acrR upstream of the acrAB operon in E. coli suggests that the operon may be controlled at the level of transcription by this regulator |CITS [ 8821940]|.
LeuO can fully antagonize the negative effect of H-NS on the bglGFB operon |CITS: [9422614]|.

BglJ induces bgl operon expression via unknown mechanisms |CITS:[8725214][16207917]|. A modest effect was observed on expression of the bglGFB operon during the stationary phase by the BglJ transcriptional regulator in the absence of rpoS/crl |CITS:[18793199]|.
The response regulator RcsB can form heterodimers with RcsA |CITS:[9341681]| and GadE |CITS:[20189963]| and it forms heterodimers with BglJ to activate the transcription of the bgl operon |CITS:[20952573]|.
The RcsB-BglJ heteromer activates transcription of bglG synergistically with CRP, where it shifts the transcription start by 20 bp from a position typical for class I CRP-dependent promoters (bglGp) to a position typical for class II CRP-dependent promoters (bglGp2) |CITS:[24335284]|.
Activation of bglGp2 by RcsB-BglJ is CRP dependent, and the AR2 region of CRP is not involved in coactivation of this promoter by either regulator |CITS:[24335284]|. BglJ-RcsB and CRP synergistically activate the bglGp2 promoter and relieve repression by HNS and StpA.

GadE is the main activator of the hdeAB-yhiD operon. Both H-NS and GadE are involved in increasing the hdeAB-yhiD repression levels by MarA that occur as the cell enters the stationary phase |CITS: [18083817]|.

Microarray analyses have shown that the hdeD gene is activated by the transcriptional regulator GadX, but it is not known if the effect of the regulator on the gene is direct or indirect. The positive regulation of hdeD by GadX is positively influenced by the transcriptional regulator GadW |CITS: [12730179]|.
GadX has a positive direct or indirect effect on the hdeAB-yhiD operon only in stationary-phase cells at pH 5.5, but it is a repressor in exponential growth phase at pH 7.0 |CITS: [18083817]|.
ArgP binds the lysPp promoter upstream region, with a Kd of 55 nM |CITS:[21890697]|.

GadE is the main activator of the hdeAB-yhiD operon. Both H-NS and GadE are involved in increasing the hdeAB-yhiD repression levels by MarA that occur as the cell enters the stationary phase |CITS: [18083817]|.

Fraikin et al. |CITS: [31848281]| showed that MqsA does not regulate the rpoS promoter. The authors reported that the regulation observed in previous experiments could be nonspecific due to the disproportionate overexpression of the protein used in those earlier experiments.
Three putative DpiA-binding sites, which are A+T-rich sequences, are located upstream of the citC gene |CITS: [9701802]|.

Based on microarray analysis it was concluded that anaerobiosis does not affect the expression of the purMN operon, although FNR appears to repress it. A putative FNR-binding site, which was not shown in the paper, was identified in this operon |CITS: [12754220]|.
It was demonstrated that PhoP is able to activate the expression of each gene in the operon |CITS:[21029047]|.
Repression of mtl transcription occurs only when both MtlR and Fis are expressed.
Through of overexpression analysis, BaeR and EvgA were shown to mediated βB-lactam as a result of induction of the multidrug exporter acrD gene expression |CITS: [12951338]|.
Most of the transcription of the uvrC gene begins at the uvrCp2 promoter |CITS:[2556297]|.

The cAMP-CRP complex inhibits the puuDRCBE operon in the presence of 0.04% (2.22 mM) glucose |CITS:[23719730]|.

CRP regulates positively the activation of the rmf gene for formation of 100S ribosome dimers |CITS: [23475967]|. rmfp expression is increased during the transition from exponential- to stationary-phase growth |CITS: [2181444][11168583][23475967]|.

Although the ptrAp promoter lacks a canonical LexA sequence, it is recognized by LexA based on ChIP-chip analysis and mutation site experiments |CITS: [16264194]|. This aberrant version of the LexA motif suggests that another transcription factor could be involved in the regulation of the ptrAp promoter in vivo |CITS: [16264194]|.
CRP site I is also called promoter-proximal, and it plays a major role in cspDp activation by CRP |CITS:[24509317]|.
CRP site II site is also called distal-promoter, and it plays a minor role in cspDp activation by CRP |CITS:[24509317]|.

Venkatesh et al. in 2010 showed that the formation of heterodimers between RcsB and the BglJ stabilizes the interaction with the distant binding site to the bglG operon. They also determined that the binding target for the RcsB-BglJ heterodimer consists of a 14-nucleotide sequence (TTTATAAATTCCTA), and they suggested that RcsB is a regulator that may interact with the right half (ATTCCTA) of this binding site while BglJ interacts with the left half (TTTATAA) of the same binding site |CITS:[20952573]|.
The RcsB-BglJ heteromer activates transcription of bglG synergistically with CRP, where it shifts the transcription start by 20 bp from a position typical for class I CRP-dependent promoters (bglGp) to a position typical for class II CRP-dependent promoters (bglGp2) |CITS:[24335284]|.
Activation of bglGp2 by RcsB-BglJ is CRP dependent, and the AR2 region of CRP is not involved in coactivation of this promoter by either regulator |CITS:[24335284]|. BglJ-RcsB and CRP synergistically activate the bglGp2 promoter and relieve repression by HNS and StpA.

HipB represses relA expression, and HipA enhances this repression through direct interaction with HipB, increasing its expression 36.8%, significantly higher than that by HipB alone |CITS: [24089053]|.

CRP box 1 (-90.5) activates pck expression only in the presence of low levels of cAMP-CRP |CITS:[24814025]|. However, the activation of pck by CRP is not clear, based on in vitro experiments. It is possible that there is a yet-unidentified supporting factor for transcription activation in vivo of the pck gene, as in the case of Cra, which positively regulates the expression of pck |CITS:[ 8577250]|.
CRP box 2 (+13.5) represses pck expression only in the presence of high levels of cAMP-CRP |CITS:[24814025]|.
OmpR-P represses biofilm production by direct interaction of the pgaABCD operon through acetyl phosphate as the phosphodonor |CITS:[25667010]|.

Fraikin et al. |CITS: [31848281]| showed that MqsA does not regulate the csgD promoter. The authors reported that the regulation observed in previous experiments could be nonspecific due to the disproportionate overexpression of the protein used in those earlier experiments.

The regulatory effect of NtrC on the promoter patAp is as yet not known |CITS: [12617754]|. However, we assigned a positive role to this regulatory interaction based on the facts that NtrC activates σ54 promoters and the promoter patAp is one of them.

By making use of microarray analyses, Constantinidou et al. |CITS: [16377617]| concluded that FNR activates ompW gene expression. They also identified a putative FNR-binding site upstream of the gene, but the sequence was not shown.
The RI site (-113.5) has the highest affinity, since protection occurred at a low concentration of CRP (50 nM) |CITS:[27551019] |.
This site (-160.5) is called RII |CITS:[27551019] |.
This site (-191.5) is called RIII |CITS:[27551019] |.

The effect of IHF at the upstream region of rpoEp1b was determined based on that position; IHF usually functions as an activator of the transcription |CITS: [27629414]|. However, based on gene expression analysis, it was determined that IHF represses rpoE expression |CITS:[29196655]|.
At low levels of nitrate, NarL activates nrfA expression and at high levels of nitrate NarL represses it.
Hns modulates the hlyE expression both positively and negatively; this protein enhances the CRP-mediated expression of hlyE , but it inhibits the FNR-mediated hlyE expression.

The maximum nirB expression is achieved at high nitrate concentrations through the proteins NarL and NarP, which function independently of each other, but NarL appears to be the main activator. The nitrite is a less effective inductor of nirB expression |CITS: [11004182]|.
NarL counteracts the repressive effect of IHF (-88 site) and Fis (-142 site). This site interferes with the binding of IHF (-88 site). However, IHF cannot displace prebound NarL. Browning et al. |CITS: [15225315]| suggested that NarL interferes with IHF (-88 binding site) at the nir promoter by distorting the minor groove at its target site, and they argued that the resulting activation by NarL results from remodeling of the local nucleoprotein structure to facilitate FNR-dependent transcription.

Two large footprinting regions for Hns binding, which are necessary for full repression, were identified around the regulatory region of the gadXp promoter (from +1 to -67 and from -86 to -153 ) . These regions may contain sites for several Hns molecules, but these specific sites have
not been identified |CITS:[15795232]|.
The RNA polymerase binding to the gadXp promoter can be prevented by Hns protein that binds around the promoter region |CITS:[15795232]|.
Salmon et al. |CITS: [15699038]| identified a putative ArcA-binding site upstream of the rpsJp promoter, but the sequence was not reported.
MatA-matAp1 regulatory interaction was identified in Escherichia coli strain IHE 3034 |CITS:[ 22422754]|.
CAP and NagC can bind simultaneously and produce a more stable complex than binary NagC-DNA complex. This is a weak CAP binding site.

Direct FruR binding to acnB has been determined, even though a repressive effect is observed. The different effect of FruR on acnA (activating) and acnB (repressing) is yet unclear. It may be related to the preferential use of one of the two enzymes in the citric and glyoxylate cycles or stress response (see |CITS: [9421904]|).
The regulatory effect of FlhDC in the glpA operon transcription has been proved only by microarray analysis by |CITS: [11287152]|.

By making use of microarray analyses, Constantinidou et al. |CITS: [16377617]| concluded that FNR activates tar-tap-cheRBYZ operon expression. They also identified a putative FNR-binding site upstream of the operon, but the sequence was not reported.

Under microaerobic conditions, ArcA activates cydD expression.
Growth Condition-chip-Experiment: Escherichia coli MG1655/arcA-8myc/M9 minimal medium/glucose 0.2%; ammonium chloride 0.1%; potassium nitrate 20 mmol/anaerobiosis/37Â°C/exponential phase |CITS:[24699140]|.
Growth Conditions_GeneExpression_CONTROL: Escherichia coli MG1655/arcA knockout mutant/M9 minimal medium/glucose 0.2%; ammonium chloride 0.1%/anaerobiosis/37Â°C/exponential phase |CITS:[24699140]|.

Yang et al. identified the binding site of PhoB |CITS:[ 23071782]| but did not identify the promoter regulated; therefore, there is a possibility that this binding site corresponds to another promoter, according to the function of PhoB. The binding site of this regulator, gCATGACAACATTGTGAAA, is located at bp -21 relative to the translation start site of yhjC |CITS:[ 23071782]|.

By making use of microarray analyses it was concluded that FNR activates pst operon expression under anaerobiosis. A putative FNR-binding site, which was not shown in the paper, was identified upstream of this operon |CITS: [12754220]|.

No DNA consensus sequence that is recognized by FliZ has been established. Therefore, for this DNA-binding site we added the complete region, determined by footprinting analysis |CITS:[22323519]|, to which FliZ binds.
Paradoxically, even though H-NS is an inhibitor, it drives the bound RNA polymerase into open complexes |CITS: [15686546]|.

Although no CytR-binding sites have been identified, it was suggested that the CytR protein could bind cooperatively to a region between the two CRP-binding sites, as in the regulatory regions of the deo and cdd operons |CITS: [8022285]|.
It was not identified which of two promoters of the als operon was repressed by AlsR, but we inferred that both are repressed, because they are very closed.

The AppY protein is also involved in anaerobic induction of the hya operon, which encodes hydrogenase 1 and is located immediately upstream from the appCBA operon. The AppY protein regulates AppA synthesis by activating transcription from the appCp promoter. Furthermore, the appY gene might be autoregulated. Genetic analysis of the appCp promoter region indicates that the presence of sequences upstream from the -10 region are required for activation of the appCp promoter by AppY protein and anaerobiosis, suggesting that this region has an AppY-binding site.
CRP and CytR bind cooperatively to cddp.

Even though the FruR site has not been determined for the acnA gene, the FruR effect in its transcription is correlated. It has been proposed that FruR affects the acnAp2 promoter because this is responsible for the basal level of acnA during exponential growth as well as redox stress |CITS: [9421904]|.

MatA-fliCp regulatory interaction was identified in Escherichia coli strain IHE 3034 |CITS:[ 22422754]|.
MatA binds weakly to fliCp |CITS:[ 22422754]|.
CAP and NagC can bind simultaneously and produce a more stable complex than binary NagC-DNA complex.
A putative DpiA-binding site, which is an A+T-rich sequence, is located upstream of the appY gene |CITS: [9701802]|.
GcvA interacts with the RNA polymerase α-subunit to activate gcvTp |CITS:[15621456]|.

HipB represses relA expression, and HipA enhances this repression through direct interaction with HipB, increasing its expression 36.8%, significantly higher than that by HipB alone |CITS: [24089053]|.
CdaR responds to the inducers D-glycerate, D-galactarate, D-glucarate, and 2-D-mannosyl-glycerate.
During anaerobiosis, a fis mutation enhances fumB expression about 30% compared with the wild type.

By making use of microarray analyses it was concluded that anarobiosis does not affect expression of the ssu operon, although FNR appears to activate it. A putative FNR-binding site, which was not shown in the report, was identified in this operon |CITS: [12754220]|.

Isolated mRNA from isogenic himA+ and himA::Tn10 (SR69 and SR1021) strains or from himD mutant bacteria (SR1022) has been studied. The primer extension results showed comparatively low levels of mRNA transcripts initiating from all three putative promoters. Thus, it is clear that functional IHF is needed for efficient transcription of the ecp-htrE operon.

By making use of microarray analyses, it was concluded that FNR activates bcsBZ operon expression under anaerobiosis. A putative FNR-binding site, which is not shown in the paper, was identified upstream of this operon |CITS: [12754220]|.

Additional evidence supports this TF-gene interaction with no precise position defined.

Based on studies of binding sites using gel shift and footprinting with Lrp and H-NS regulator proteins, it was demonstrated that both proteins interact with obvious synergism in the repression of all seven E. coli rrn P1 promoter upstream regions; as a result, they help the efficient shutdown of rRNA synthesis. Likewise, both proteins could be a transient heteromer via protein-protein interactions interfering with the RNA polymerase, and this way it may alter the DNA of the upstream regions of all seven ribosomal P1 promoters |CITS: [16238633]|.
Generally, Fur binds to 19 bp in DNA, but in this case it binds to 25 bp upstream from the entSp1 promoter.

Two large footprinting regions for Hns binding, which are necessary for full repression, were identified around the regulatory region of the gadAp promoter (from +43 to -55 and from -86 to -133). These regions may contain sites for several Hns molecules, but these specific sites have not been identified |CITS:[15795232]|.
The RNA polymerase binding to the gadAp promoter can be prevented by the Hns protein which binds around the promoter region. Also, on the same region GadX can bind, competing with Hns for the same site; even GadX can remove the already-bound Hns |CITS:[15795232]| .

Microarray analyses have shown that the hdeD gene is activated by the transcriptional regulator GadX, but it is not known if the effect of the regulator on the gene is direct or indirect. The positive regulation of hdeD by GadX is positively influenced by the transcriptional regulator GadW |CITS: [12730179]|.
CRP activates the fisP1 promoter in the absence of FIS, but if FIS is present, together FIS and CRP repress fis gene transcription.
AppY actives the transcription of the hyaABCDEF operon during anaerobic growth.
NarL repressed the ubiCA operon under anaerobiosis.
It appears that the negative effects of ArcA and Fnr on aceE are not additive |CITS:[15988767]|.
The regulatory effect of FlhDC in hydN operon transcription has been proved only by a microarray analysis by |CITS: [11287152]|.

By making use of microarray analyses, Constantinidou et al. |CITS: [16377617]| concluded that FNR activates garPLRK-rnpB operon expression. They also identified a putative FNR-binding site upstream of the operon, but the sequence was not shown.
The effect of AdiY on adiA expression is most readily detected at pH 8.0.

Baek and Lee demonstrated that the protein PhoB positively regulates transcription initiation of the gene ytfK in strain W3110, a strain derived from the K-12 strain |CITS:[17020555]|. They also proposed a putative Pho box to be recognized by PhoB, but it overlaps with the identified transcriptional start site. On the other hand, based on DNase I footprinting analysis, Yoshida et al. demostrated that in E. coli strain O157:H7, the protein PhoB recognizes and binds to two transcription factor-binding sites (TFBSs) located upstream of the transcriptional start site of ytfK |CITS:[21538251]|.The E. coli strains W3110 and MG1655 contain a sequence, upstream of ytfK, that is identical to the one mentioned above for O157:H7; therefore, taking into account the results above, we have added the regulation reported by Baek and Lee (|CITS:[ 17020555]| using the TFBS identified by Yoshida et al. |CITS:[21538251]|.

Additional evidence supports this TF-gene interaction with no precise position defined.

GadX has a positive direct or indirect effect on the hdeAB-yhiD operon only in stationary-phase cells at pH 5.5, but it is a repressor in exponential growth phase at pH 7.0 |CITS: [18083817]|.

Although H-NS cannot activate relAp2 by itself, it can positively regulate relAp2 activity together with CRP, since H-NS induces conformational changes in the relAp2 transcriptional region that facilitate the CRP binding |CITS: [17159291]|.

By making use of microarray analyses, Constantinidou et al. |CITS: [16377617]| concluded that FNR represses ygbA gene expression. They also identified a putative FNR-binding site upstream of the gene, but the sequence was not shown.
MarA represses rob by steric hindrance |CITS:[20453091]|. This mar box has a backward orientation |CITS:[20453091]|.
Lrp is a specific repressor for σ38-dependent transcription of the aidB promoter. Activation of the aidB promoter by Ada is dominant over repression by Lrp in vitro.

The maximum nrfA expression is achieved at low nitrate concentrations through NarP and mainly through NarL. Wang and Gunsalus |CITS: [11004182]| reported that the nitrite is a less effective inductor of nrfA expression, although in a earlier report Page et al. |CITS: [2173895]| reported that this molecule was the primary signal. The sites at -70 and -79 are recognized by NarL and NarP, but NarL has the highest affinity for them.
nrf expression is increased in response to nitrite or nitrate ions by NarL or NarP. FNR and NarL/NarP act by promoting open complex formation by RNAP at the nrf promoter. Although it seems that NarL and FNR can bind to their targets independently, NarL is unable to activate the nrf promoter in the absence of FNR |CITS: [15978080]|. NarL and IHF cannot bind together; the other protein regulators can bind together to form ternary complexes. Fis binds independently of FNR and IHF. |CITS: [15978080]| supposed that Fis blocks access of RNAP to the nrf promoter.

Based on studies of binding sites determined using gel shift and footprinting analyses with Lrp and H-NS regulator proteins, it was demonstrated that both proteins interact with obvious synergism in the repression of all seven E. coli rrn P1 promoter upstream regions; as a result, they help the efficient shutdown of rRNA synthesis. Likewise, both proteins could be a transient heteromer via a protein-protein interaction interfering with the RNA polymerase, and this way they may alter the DNA of the upstream regions of all seven ribosomal P1 promoters |CITS: [16238633]|.

ArcA represses gatY gene expression under anaerobiosis. Two putative ArcA-binding sites were identified upstream of this gene, but their sequence was not shown |CITS: [15699038]|.

NarL appears to bind two regions upstream of the fdhF promoter: one of them is between position -130 and position ?175 and the other one is between position -190 and position -27 relative to the transcription start site. NarP appears to antagonize the ability of NarL to repress fdhF gene expression.

By making use of microarray analyses it was concluded that FNR activates acrEF operon expression under anaerobiosis. A putative FNR-binding site, which was not reported in the paper, was identified upstream of this operon |CITS: [12754220]|.
The ade gene is repressed 10-fold by HNS. On the other hand, it was demonstrated that some insertion elements are able to eliminate the HNS-mediated silencing of ade |CITS:[ 12077137]|.
Hns repress adiAp promoter at pH 8.0

Yang et al. identified the binding site of PhoB |CITS:[ 23071782]| but did not identify the promoter regulated; therefore, there is a possibility that this binding site corresponds to another promoter, according to the function of PhoB. The binding site of this regulator, TTGTATGACAAATGTCACA, is located at bp -31 relative to the translation start site of yegH |CITS:[ 23071782]|.

In the absence of the other proteins, cAMP-CRP binds to three CRP targets centered at -92.5 (CRP2), -42.5 (CRP1), and +56 (CRPE).
The nupG full repression complex contains CytR protein sandwiched between two cAMP-CRP complexes.

Under anaerobiosis, FNR represses rpsJ gene expression, but it is not known if this regulation is direct or indirect |CITS: [12754220]|. We assigned this regulation to the rrpsJ-rplCDWB-rpsS-rplV-rpsC-rplP-rpmC-rpsQ operon because it is known that the rpsJ gene is transcribed as a part of this operon.

Rob is a transcriptional regulator related to the increase in resistance to antibiotics and is expressed constitutively. Bennik et al. have shown that this regulator activates the transcription of the ybiS gene |CITS [ 10850996 ]|.
Rob binding to zwf induced a bend of ~30°.
|CITS:[9663683]| mentioned that they do not know if the inhibitory effect of H-NS on transcription from osmCp1 is direct or indirect. The effect on osmCp1 was independent of σS.

The exact position where ComR binds to the bhsA gene is not known. However, it has been suggested that ComR binds to a 60 bp region upstream of the bhsA gene, based on analysis of PCR fragments |CITS: [22089859]|.
Currently, it seems that bhsA is a unique gene of the nearly up- and downstream comR/bhsA region regulated by ComR |CITS: [22089859]|.
Induction by copper is the principal regulation mechanism of the bhsA gene |CITS: [22089859]|.

No DNA consensus sequence that is recognized by FliZ has been established. Therefore, for this DNA-binding site we added the complete region, determined by footprinting analysis |CITS:[22323519]|, to which FliZ binds.

Based on studies of binding sites determined using gel shift and footprinting analyses with Lrp and H-NS regulator proteins, it was demonstrated that both proteins interact with obvious synergism in the repression of all seven E. coli rrn P1 promoter upstream regions; as a result, they help the efficient shutdown of rRNA synthesis. Likewise, both proteins could be a transient heteromer via a protein-protein interaction interfering with the RNA polymerase, and this way they may alter the DNA of the upstream regions of all seven ribosomal P1 promoters |CITS: [16238633]|.

By making use of microarray analyses, Constantinidou et al. |CITS: [16377617]| concluded that FNR activates pepT gene expression. They also identified a putative FNR-binding site upstream of the pepT gene, but the sequence was not shown.

CRP is required for lgoR and lgoD transcription in a sugar-independent manner, irrespective of whether the bacteria are grown with glucose or glucuronate as the main carbon source |CITS: [27129867]|, and this might be due to its cAMP-independent binding to a nonspecific site leading to only a secondary effect |CITS: [8394684]|.
The recQ gene is under the control of the SOS system through the LexA transcriptional repressor |CITS:[3027506]|.
The FisI (-26) binding site has a relatively low affinity for its cognate factor, which ensures that it is only occupied during rapid growth |CITS:[18452510]|.
tcyP transcription is activated by CysB when cysteine is scarce |CITS:[ 26350134]|. There is a likely CysB-binding site 100 bp upstream of the promoter |CITS:[ 26350134]|.
DnaA and LexA compete for binding to and regulation of the uvrBp3 promoter, as the DnaA-box6 overlaps with LexA-box4 during the SOS response |CITS:[29967594]|.
Repression of the glaH-lhgO-gabDTP operon by GlaR transcription factor is selectively relieved by glutarate |CITS:[30498244]|.

Under acid stress at pH 6.5, OmpR repressed the cadC gene, thus eliminating proton consumption and acidifying the cytoplasm |CITS:[29138484]|.
OmpR in its dimeric state binds DNA, but phosphorylation of OmpR is not required |CITS:[29138484]|.
PhoB inhibits the clpS expression under low cytoplasmic Mg2+, and the resulting impact on abundance of a ClpSAP substrate is conserved between E. coli and Salmonella |CITS: [29686082]|.

TorR shows no significant effect in the expression of hdeAB-yhiD, which suggests that TorR only regulates the hdeAB-yhiD operon after induction of the TorRS system by trimethylamine, N-oxide, and anaerobiosis |CITS: [12657056] [18083817]|. Two predicted sites have been reported |CITS: [18083817]|.

LexA binds tightly to LexA-box1 at the uvrBp1 and uvrBp2 promoters, irrespective of the presence of DnaA, and this binding is important for the control of the uvrBp1 and uvrBp2 promoters |CITS:[29967594]|.
Based on microarray and RT-qPCR analyses, it was determined that the fecA and frdB genes are downregulated upon exposure to glutathione (GSH) |CITS:[29468195]|.

TorR shows no significant effect in the expression of hdeAB-yhiD, which suggests that TorR only regulates the hdeAB-yhiD operon after induction of the TorRS system by trimethylamine, N-oxide, and anaerobiosis |CITS: [12657056] [18083817]|. Two predicted sites have been reported |CITS: [18083817]|.

The ArcA binding site was predicted to be within a narrow sequence near 100 bp upstream from the Rsd coding sequence. The known consensus sequence recognized by ArcA, 5Â´-(AT)GTTAATTA(AT)-3, exists in the upstream region of the rsd gene |CITS:[ 30225374]|.
rsd expression is repressed by ArcA during the exponential growth phase |CITS:[ 30225374]|.

LexA binds tightly to LexA-box1 at the uvrBp1 and uvrBp2 promoters, irrespective of the presence of DnaA, and this binding is important for the control of the uvrBp1 and uvrBp2 promoters |CITS:[29967594]|.

DnaA and LexA compete for binding to and regulation of the uvrBp3 promoter, as DnaA-box6 overlaps with LexA-box4. The transcription control of uvrBp3 largely depends on DnaA-box6 during the SOS response |CITS:[29967594]|.

Under acid stress at pH 6.5, OmpR repressed the cadBA operon to eliminate proton consumption and acidify the cytoplasm |CITS:[29138484]|.
The cadBA operon was the major system that eliminated protons upon acid stress over the approximate pH range of 6.1-6.5 |CITS: [29138484]|.
OmpR in its dimeric state binds DNA, but phosphorylation of OmpR is not required |CITS:[29138484]|.

REGULATORY_INTERACTION_NOTE.br:
During the exponential phase and under oxidative stress, elaB expression is induced in an OxyR- and RpoS-dependent way, but during stationary phase, elaB does not need OxyR or RpoS to induce its expression; even OxyR represses the expression of elaB under these growth conditions |CITS: [30656833]|.
In addition to the TFBS located at -31 from the TSS, there is another TFBS located at -358.5 from the TSS of the promoter of elaB that could bind to OxyR. However, it appears not to be important for elaB regulation by OxyR, because when this site is mutated no changes in expression are observed |CITS:[ 30656833]|.

ROW.REGULATORY_INTERACTION_NOTE: The DNA binding site required to repress the expression of the lac operon by MarA (marbox) is located in the reverse orientation of the transcription start site and overlaps the -35 element of the promoter lacZp1 |CITS: [30850424]|.

The gene expression of hicA was analyzed in a mutant of Sxy, a protein that is known to be a coregulator of CRP. The CRP effect on hicA expression was inferred from the results of gene expression analysis using the Sxy mutant |CITS: [28266056]|.

It seems that TorR is able to regulate itself in an unphosphorylated conformation, because it autorepresses well in the absence of phosphate donors such as trimethylamine N-oxide (TMAO) and TorS |CITS: [10648521]|.
When HicA is in excess in the cell, it appears to destabilize the binding of HicB to DNA, causing the derepression of hicAB transcription |CITS: [28266056]|.

It seems that TorR is able to regulate itself in an unphosphorylated conformation, because it autorepresses well in the absence of phosphate donors such as trimethylamine N-oxide (TMAO) and TorS |CITS: [10648521]|.

REGULATORY_INTERACTION_NOTE.br:
During the exponential phase and under oxidative stress, elaB expression is induced in an OxyR- and RpoS-dependent way, but during stationary phase, elaB does not need OxyR or RpoS to induce its expression; even OxyR represses the expression of elaB under these growth conditions |CITS: [30656833]|.
In addition to the TFBS located at -31 from the TSS, there is another TFBS located at -358.5 from the TSS of the promoter of elaB that could bind to OxyR. However, it appears not to be important for elaB regulation by OxyR, because when this site is mutated no changes in expression are observed |CITS:[ 30656833]|.

The ycgZp promoter is recognized by both σ70- and σ38-associated RNA polymerase. The marbox position is important for σ70-dependent activation of the ycgZp promoter |CITS: [31518447]|. On the other hand, MarA activates σ38-dependent transcription from a ycgZp promoter derivative with a repositioned marbox |CITS: [31518447]|.
MarA regulates the ycgZ-ymgA-ariR-ymgC operon for inhibition of biofilm formation and Curli fiber formation, and it is required for induction by salicylic acid in vivo |CITS: [31518447]|.
DcuR appears to affect the expression of aspAp in response to fumarate |CITS: [31734389]|.
DcuR appears to affect the expression of pck in response to fumarate |CITS: [31734389]|.
DcuR appears to affect the expression of aspAp in response to fumarate |CITS: [31734389]|.
DcuR appears to affect the expression of pck in response to fumarate |CITS: [31734389]|.

GadE is required both for gadA/gadBC expression during exponential growth and stationary-phase expression. GadE is an acid-induced regulator since it is involved in the acid induction of gadA/gadBC operons during exponential growth. The expression of these operons may be one of the most intensively regulated systems in Escherichia coli, since it is regulated by different factors. GadE and GadX may simultaneously bind to the GAD box region of gadA/gadBC and form a complex |CITS: [12940989]|.

No DNA consensus sequence that is recognized by FliZ has been established. Therefore, for this DNA-binding site we added the complete region, determined by footprinting analysis |CITS:[22323519]|, to which FliZ binds.
Fis binding to this site functions as an anti-activator of CRP.

BasR activates transcription of the emrD gene, which decreases susceptibility of several antimicrobial agents, such as ciprofloxacin, norfloxacin, doxycycline, tetracycline, clindamycin, lincomycin, erythromycin, and SDS in the Escherichia coli strains APECX40 and MG1655 |CITS:[32379525]|.

Slow concentration of StpA activates the casAp promoter in an H-NS mutant, but when StpA is overexpressed it is not able to activate the promoter |CITS: [32385085]|. StpA binds to the same DNA binding site as H-NS does, upstream of casAp, but StpA and H-NS cause opposite regulatory effects |CITS: [32385085]|.

The ycgZp promoter is recognized by both σ70- and σ38-associated RNA polymerase. The marbox position is important for σ70-dependent activation of the ycgZp promoter |CITS: [31518447]|. On the other hand, MarA activates σ38-dependent transcription from a ycgZp promoter derivative with a repositioned marbox |CITS: [31518447]|.
MarA regulates the ycgZ-ymgA-ariR-ymgC operon for inhibition of biofilm formation and Curli fiber formation, and it is required for induction by salicylic acid in vivo |CITS: [31518447]|.
CRP has a positive effect on dgsAp2 transcription directed by σ70. However, CRP has little effect on dgsAp2 transcription directed by σ32.

The regulatory effect of IHF on the promoter micFp1 is not yet known. However, we have assigned a negative effect to this regulatory interaction based on the fact that the protein's binding site overlaps the transcription start site of the promoter.

Likewise, both proteins could be a transient heteromer via protein-protein interaction interfering with the RNA polymerase, and this way it alters the DNA of the upstream regions of all seven ribosomal P1 promoters |CITS: [16238633]|.

OxyR regulates gor gene expression in response to H2O2 during the exponential phase. This gene was induced by rpoS in stationary phase |CITS:[8593953]|.

The site for IHF (-173.5), determined experimentally by DNase I footprinting, covers a region of 30 bp upstream of csgDp1 |CITS: [20466769]|]. It is likely that there are several sites for IHF, so the consensus sequence for this regulator is 13 bp.

In a DNase I footprinting analysis of the rrnEp region, several regions of Lrp protection were observed to extend from position -100 upstream into the downstream transcription region. Specific central positions for the Lrp transcriptional regulator were not determined. It is important to note that the same sequence is strongly protected by the H-NS-DNA complex |CITS: [16238633]|.

The regulatory effect of MetJ on the promoter metKp is not yet known. However, we assigned a negative effect to this regulatory interaction based on two facts: the protein's binding site is very close to the promoter, and MetJ is known to act, so far without exceptions, as a negative regulator.

Additional evidence supports this TF-gene interaction with no precise position defined.

The AppY protein is also involved in anaerobic induction of the hya operon, which encodes hydrogenase 1 and is located immediately upstream from the appCBA operon. The AppY protein regulates AppA synthesis by activating transcription from the appCp promoter. Furthermore, the appY gene might be autoregulated. Genetic analysis of the appCp promoter region indicates that the presence of sequences upstream from the -10 region are required for activation of the appCp promoter by AppY protein and anaerobiosis, suggesting that this region has an AppY-binding site.
